EVENT_NARRATIVE:
Russel Foster, Anchorage, his girlfriend and five
other snowmachiners were with a group riding in the Chugach
National Forest off Palmer Creek Road near the old Swetmann Mine
Sunday.

Sometime after 1 p.m., Foster, 35, headed up a slope above
the rest of the riders, according to State trooper reports.  A
friend, Bobby Frankson, was below him when the snowpack on the
side of the mountain let loose.

The avalanche buried Foster.  Frankson went for help.

Snowmachiners found foster through a signal emitted by his
avalanche beacon.  The searchers used probe poles to identify his
precise location, and dug Foster out from about 3.5 to 4 feet of
hard packed snow.  At least 30 minutes had elapsed since the
avalanche.

Two hours of CPR failed to revive Foster, who became the
third avalanche fatality in Alaska this winter.

Conditions were prime for avalanches for several
weeks.  This mix of extreme cold, punctuated by several 'warm'
storms, has made the snowpack especially unstable, according to
avalanche experts.  On the bottom is a layer of very weak sugary
snow (faceted snow) that formed during the cold periods.  Above
that is heavier, denser snow that fell during the warmer periods,
and wind packed snow.  In between are thin layers of surface
hoarfrost and ice. Forecasts adequately reflected weather that
developed across the area. A message from a private avalanche
group regarding avalanche classes at the beginning of January was
broadcast on Alaska Weather"

The slide path was small, only 200 feet wide by 250 feet vertical, yet it broke 2-3 feet deep on the ice crust and facets. A rider got stuck and then two friends rode up to help him, which triggered the slide. A low pressure center in Bristol Bay on the morning of the 22nd moved north into the interior near Fairbanks that evening.  The low then moved northeast and dissipated by 9pm on the 23rd, but high pressure which had resided over eastern Russia moved east over western Alaska and into the Interior on the 23rd.  On the 22nd, a weather front associated with the low brought strong winds and local blizzards to the Alaska Range, and the low itself created strong winds and blizzards over Cape Romanzof on the west coast. Heavy snows were generated over the western and northern interior, and in the Alaska Range.  Ahead of the front over the interior southeast of Fairbanks, freezing rain fell over zone 226 and parts of zone 224. 

Winter Storm/Avalanche:
Zone 225 - Parks Highway mile 218 near Panorama Peak, just north of Cantwell and south of Denali National Park. Unofficial reports noted that the avalanche covered the highway for up to a quarter of a mile to a depth of 16 feet. The highway was closed for nearly 2 days. There were no deaths or injuries from this avalanche, though one truck with an empty propane trailer encountered the edge of the moving snow mass.  Snow fall amounts in the area of the avalanche were reported to be 12-16 inches by the D.O.T.  At the Denali Park Co-operative observing station, 7.5 inches of snow was recorded by 0800AST on the 23rd, with snow beginning around 0800 on the 22nd.  The avalanche knocked out power to the community of Cantwell for 6 to 8 hours on the 23rd, and in the Denali Park Entrance on the 23rd and into the 24th. The Parks Highway was closed at Panorama Peak most of the 23rd and the 24th. Land transportation of mail and goods was halted between Fairbanks and Anchorage, as the Richardson Highway from Delta Junction through Isabel Pass was noted to have treacherous driving conditions from the sleet, freezing rain, and blowing snow.  Blizzard conditions followed the heavy snowfall as north winds developed due to the high pressure over western Alaska moving into the interior.  This hampered quick removal of the snow on the Parks Highway.
Zone 226 - The Richardson Highway between Delta Junction and Paxson was closed on the 23rd and not reopened until the 26th due to large snow drifts from blowing snow. A stalled storm system just off the southern California coast was able to tap abundant tropical moisture from the central Equatorial Pacific Ocean and dump copious amounts of rain and wet snow on many portions of Utah. The relatively warm air ahead of the storm raised snow levels and rain fell on an already deep snowpack and resulted in the second costliest natural disaster in state history. An estimated $300 million in damage was reported from flooding along the Santa Clara and Virgin Rivers in Washington County. One man was killed in the flooding near Quail Creek Reservior and three people perished in avalanches. The Virgin River water level reached a 25-year high and the Santa Clara River rose above any previously recorded level. 30 homes were destroyed as the Santa Clara changed course and cut through a portion of the community. Approximately 20 more homes were significantly damaged during this record flood event. This storm system also brought heavy and wet snowfall to elevations above 8000 feet. Many avalanches occurred throughout the state following the storm. A large avalanche killed a snowboarder in Ephraim Canyon. East of Mount Pleasant, a slide took the life of a snowmobiler.

Abineau Canyon is on the north side of the San Francisco Peaks within the Kachina Peaks Wilderness Area about 10 miles north of Flagstaff. The head of the canyon is over 12,000 feet above sea level and the toe of the avalanche was around 9,500 feet. Arizona Snowbowl, only 3 miles away, reported their second highest seasonal snowfall of 460 inches by the end of April.

The victims two companions along with two skiers from another party witnessed the avalanche and began a beacon search of the lenghy slide path, and soon located the victim at the bottom of the slide zone, on top of the snow. The victim was airlifted to Telluride and then to Grand Junction for medical treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a moist zonal flow and strong upper level jet stream brought extensive blowing and drifting snow to the North-Central Mountains of Colorado.  Wind sensors above timberline measured peak gusts from 75 to 92 mph.  The combination of snow and wind resulted in whiteout conditions and a high avalanche danger along the Interstate 70 Corridor, from Floyd Hill to Vail.  As a result, the interstate was closed for approximately 24 hours.  Other closures included:  Berthoud and Rabbit Ears Passes on U.S. Highway 40; Loveland Pass on U.S. Highway 6; Cameron Pass on State Highway 14; Kenosha Pass on U.S. Highway 285; U.S. Highways 287 and 85 near the Wyoming Border.   ||The American Red Cross opened 9 shelters in Summit County for stranded motorists; where more than 2,000 people took shelter.  Loveland Ski Area was forced to close for the day because employees and skiers couldn't get to it.  Tow truck drivers spent much of their time rescuing stranded motorists.  In Grand County, a snowmobiler was injured when he triggered an avalanche.  He was knocked unconscious and buried under 3 feet of snow.  Fortunately, he suffered only a separated shoulder.  ||Peak wind gust reports included:  92 mph at Niwot Ridge; 89 mph at Mines peak; 87 mph at Georgetown; 80 mph at Berthoud and Loveland Passes; 75 mph at Gunsight; 60 mph at Copper Mountain.  Storm totals during the 2-day period were light to moderate with amounts ranging from 5 to 10 inches.  The exception occurred at the Columbine Snotel where 15 inches of snowfall was measured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three experienced snowmobilers were riding in Smith Basin, about 15 miles east-northeast of the Co-op trailhead, when an avalanche engulfed all three of them. Two of them were able to swim out of the snow, but the third, a 41 year-old male, was buried for at least 40 minutes, and died before they could dig him out. For the state of Utah, this was the third avalanche fatality in 8 days. It was also the 7th avalanche fatality for the 2007 calendar year, the most in one year since records have been kept, starting in 1958.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three snowboarders were caught in an avalanche, leading to one fatality.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES NORTHERN CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just north of the Mount Baker ski area in the Excelsior Pass area, 2 snowmobilers died and 1 was injured in an avalanche.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just north of the Mount Baker ski area, 2 snowmobilers died and 1 was injured in an avalanche. Strong winds accompanied this weather event in portions of western Washington as well.
An avalanche buried 4 people on snowmobiles, and resulted in one fatality.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowboarder was caught and killed in a large avalanche between Vail Pass summit and East Vail. The snowboarder was engulfed by the powder cloud and was carried over 3 cliff bands and swept through numerous small pine trees before being buried about 4 feet deep, about 750 vertical feet down the slope. The other two party members quickly found the boarder but were unable to revive him.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A man was killed by an avalanche while skiing.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES NORTHERN CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 13 year old girl died in an avalanche near Verlot.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 13 year old girl died in an avalanche near Verlot. Strong winds accompanied this weather event in portions of western Washington as well along with heavy snow in the Olympics.

CZ_NAME_STR: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and winds caused four avalanches along Warm Springs Road. A garage and patio were destroyed with road closures.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and winds caused four avalanches along Warm Springs Road.  A garage and patio were destroyed with road closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over the course of about 18 hours, multiple avalanches occurred in the same area, over the Santiam Pass, near the intersection of Hwy. 20 and Hwy. 126. The avalanches were contributed to higher than average snow pack, and large amounts of plowed snow along the highways. The first set of avalanches occurred the morning of January 8th, the largest burying parts of US Hwy. 20 up to 15 feet deep.  Three cars were trapped by the avalanche then later freed, with no injuries.  The second round of avalanches occurred late at night on January 8th and wasn't cleared until the following morning.  Eight commercial vehicles were trapped for a time under the snow, with no injuries reported.  Both rounds closed the highways for an extended period of time for snow removal.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and cold Pacific system brought copious amounts of new snow accumulations to the higher elevations of northwest Oregon.  This system dropped snow levels considerably, leading to the first snow accumulation of the year in areas within the Columbia River Gorge and the Upper Hood River Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An avalanche closed Highway 62 through Crater Lake National Park.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought plenty of wind and snow to the mountains of Southern Oregon.  A Blizzard Warning was issued for Oregon zones ORZ027/028 at 07/1558 PST, effective from 07/2200 until 08/2200 PST.  The warning was shortened until 08/1900 PST (ORZ027) and 08/1600 PST (ORZ028) at 08/1437 PST.  The warning expired at 08/1900 PST (ORZ027) and 08/1600 PST (ORZ028).  A Heavy Snow Warning was issued for Oregon zones ORZ024/025 above 1500 feet at 07/1558 PST, effective from 07/1558 until 08/0600 PST.  The warning for ORZ024 was cancelled at 08/0423 PST.  The warning for ORZ025 was extended to 08/1000 PST and raised to above 2500 feet at 08/0423 PST. The effective altitude was raised to 3000 feet at 08/0525 PST.  It was extended again to 08/1600 PST at 08/1014 PST, and yet again to 08/1900 PST at 08/1437 PST.  It finally expired at 08/1900 PST.  In addition to the west side and mountain snows, heavy snow was reported at a few east side locations as well.

CZ_NAME_STR: NORTHERN SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS ABOVE 11000 FT (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A deadly avalanche occurred on the east slope of Blanca Peak.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche buried a hiker in the Hour Glass, between Blanca Peak and Little Bear Peak in the northern Sangre de Cristo mountains.

Three men were killed near Cottonwood Lake when an avalanche enveloped them and their snowmobiles.  The slide was estimated to have been one-half mile long, 400 yards wide at the bottom, and covered about 10 acres at an average depth of 10 feet in the runout zone.  The snow was powerful enough to uproot or snap trees that were two feet in diameter.  The strength of the slide allowed it to push across an open meadow and then uphill before slowing to a stop.

Two skiers were caught in an avalanche near Cache Peak about eight miles southeast of Jackson.  The slide knocked both skiers from their feet and slammed one against a tree, breaking his leg.  The partner of the injured skier used a cell phone to call for help.  Darkness prevented the pair from being rescued by helicopter.  Thus, the skiers were transported out of the wilderness approximately seven hours after the slide occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flathead County Search and Rescue personnel reported a large avalanche on the back side of Big Mountain Ski Resort. Two skiers were killed and one was injured. The avalanche was initiated by another skier who was skiing out of bounds in an area closed to skiing.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 13, a large avalanche was triggered near the Big Mountain Ski Resort.

CZ_NAME_STR: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several avalanches occurred near the Mountain High Ski Resort in the San Gabriel Mountains of Los Angeles county. Three male skiers died as a result of the avalanches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very powerful winter storm brough significant weather to Central and Southern California. This storm produced several inches of rainfall across the area. The intense rainfall produced areas of flash flooding across Ventura and Los Angeles counties, including a mud and debris flow near the Griffith Park burn area. The storm brought in a significant amounts of cold air which lowered snow levels to around 2500 feet at the height of the storm. Several inches of snowfall was reported between 2500 and 4000 feet while areas above 4000 feet received several feet of snowfall. This heavy snowfall closed Highway 33 in Ventura county as well as Interstate 5 through the Grapevine in Los Angeles county. Between 300 and 500 vehicles were stranded along Interstate 5 on Wednesday night, January 23rd. Near the Mountain High Ski Resort several avalanches occurred, killing 3 skiers. Unstable air associated with the strom system produced several reports of waterspouts west of Oxnard and Palos Verdes with one waterspout moving onshore across Point Mugu Naval Station, damaging a roof.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST SLOPES OF THE CENTRAL CASCADES (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six feet of snow in 6 days caused numerous avalanches on the mountains surrounding Interstate 90 between Easton and Snoqualmie Pass in Kittitas County.

A snowboarder triggered an avalanche on Teton Pass which closed State Highway 22 for nearly ten hours.  The avalanche occurred about 0930MST near the Twin Slides area of the pass.  The snow covered the roadway to a depth of six feet along a 120-foot-long path.  One car was partially buried by the slide but no injuries occurred.  The pass, used daily by commuters between Idaho and Jackson Hole, was finally re-opened shortly before 1900MST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three large snow and debris slides occurred along the Highway 12 corridor. The first slide occurred between 330 PM and 345 PM at mile marker 133.97, large enough to close Highway 12. The second slide occurred at mile marker 133.79 which hit a truck and trailer. The third slide at mile marker 137.06 was large enough to flow into the Lochsa River and dam up the river.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Janauary 30 and 31, another potent winter storm moved across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall, gusty winds, and signficant blowing and drifting snow.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST SLOPES OF THE CENTRAL CASCADES (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six feet of snow in 6 days caused numerous avalanches on the mountains surrounding Interstate 90 between Easton and Snoqualmie Pass in Kittitas County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Idaho Department of Transportation reported two avalanches along Highway 12. The first, at mile marker 137.79 pushed a truck into the Lochsa River. The second occurred at mile marker 133.19.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 1 and 2, a winter weather system moved across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall at Lolo Pass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three snowmobilers were coming down Little Box Canyon on a groomed trail in the southwestern Flat Tops north of the town of Rifle.  The first two riders noticed that the third was no longer behind them.|The pair turned around and headed up the canyon and found a fresh avalanche that had buried the third snowmobiler.  Rescuers retrieved the victim's body about three hours after the avalanche occurred.  The avalanche ran 300 feet down the steep slope and was 1.5 to 3 feet deep and 600 feet wide.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heavy and unstable snowpack produced an avalanche onto a snowmobile trail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clearwater Tribune reported that the Idaho State Patrol closed US Highway 95 from mile post 223-259 due to a snow avalanche on Whitebird Hill and blizzard conditions.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 5 and 6, a winter storm moved across North Central Idaho bringing heavy snow to the mountains and blizzard conditions to the Camas Prairie.
An avalanche destroyed a two-story vacation home built in 2007 near Lake Wenatchee.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two avalanches were reported along Highway 12. The first, at mile marker 133.79, covered the highway with 3 to 4 feet of debris and snow. The second, at mile marker 132.48, covered the highway with 23 feet of snow, large trees and debris.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 8-9, a winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall. The build up of snow on the mountains caused it to become unstable and produce avalanches.

Two skiers were injured, one extensively, when an avalanche triggered in a bowl they were skiing through on Casper Mountain.  The slide was 100 yards wide and at least 50-100 yards long.  One skier received only minor injuries after hitting a tree and having his skis ripped from his feet.  The second skier was buried under a foot of snow after getting one of his skis caught in the branch of a tree.  He received a deep cut to his shin and a broken foot as a result of the slide.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event was first reported over network television then in the Anchorage Daily News.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche occurred around 1 PM ADT near mile 28.5 in Thompson Pass resulting in the fatality of one man.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twenty-one natural avalanches on Red Mountain Pass hit the road and caused periods of road closure. Some of the avalanches were up to 8 feet deep and several hundred feet wide on the roadway.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and strong winds resulted in several avalanches on Red Mountain Pass.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche partially buried a skier on Berthoud Pass.  The skier suffered minor injuries.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second avalanche struck a skier on Berthoud Pass.  The person was caught and carried for some distance, but was not injured.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier was caught in a rare in-bounds avalanche on Vail Mountain. The avalanche was 100 to 150 feet wide and about 600 feet long. The skier was able to stay on top of the snow and in the end was buried waist deep in snow.  The victim's friend was able to dig him out, and the victim was not injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped heavy snow onto weak snow layers in the mountains which resulted in numerous avalanches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A ski patroller was caught in an avalanche and carried into some trees in an area known as If Cliff at an elevation near 10,800 feet.  The victim was shaken but not injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped heavy snow onto weak snow layers in the mountains which resulted in numerous avalanches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Following the snow storm the previous day, the Mt. Baldy side of Snowbird resort was open to the public for the first time in the season. Prior to the avalanche, over a period of about 3 hours, an estimated 300 people crossed the starting zone of the avalanche or skied over the slope that eventually slid. At 12:24, a male snowboarder was on the high traverse of Northwest Mt. Baldy and initiated the avalanche. A 27-year-old female, who was hiking up the slope to retrieve a ski, got caught in the avalanche and was buried; she eventually died in the hospital due to injuries sustained from the avalanche.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche in-bounds at the Snowbird ski resort resulted in one fatality.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lone backcountry skier was caught and killed in an avalanche in the Richmond Ridge area, just south of Aspen Mountain. Sometime between 1 and 3 pm the victim exited the ski resort through a backcountry gate. Since he was traveling alone, the exact time of the incident is unknown. The victim was carried about 200 vertical feet down the slope before being buried in a group of trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped heavy snow onto weak snow layers in the mountains which resulted in numerous avalanches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mammoth Times newspaper in Mammoth Lakes reported that an avalanche occurred at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Resort during early afternoon on Tuesday, December 16th.  The newspaper reported that the avalanche, in the Dragon's Tail area above Chair 9, was triggered by ski patrol performing avalanche control duties.  According to the newspaper, a small, two-foot crown broke above the ski patroller.  As a result of the avalanche carrying him down the mountain and into a tree, the patroller suffered cracked or broken ribs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One day after a powerful snowstorm deposited up to 4 feet of snowfall in the central Sierra Nevada an avalanche occurred at Mammoth Mountain Ski Resort.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sometime during the afternoon, a 36 year old male snowboarder was caught and killed in an avalanche approximately 2 miles northwest of Crested Butte. The soft slab avalanche occurred in an area known as Happy Chutes. The avalanche ran about 1,500 vertical feet, carrying the victim through a dense grove of trees, over a 20 to 30 foot cliff, then down a tight gully and finally to a stand of small trees. The victim was found about a week later under 3 to 4 feet of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowboarder was killed by an avalanche.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On Christmas Eve morning, the first clear day after several consecutive days under stormy weather conditions, four experienced snowmobilers ventured out into a common snowmobiling area at Logan Peak. They were riding near the summit of the east face of Logan Peak at the head of Providence Canyon, in an area known by local snowmobilers as the Rodeo Grounds, when an avalanche was triggered, catching and killing two of the snowmobilers.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche at Logan Peak on the morning of December 24th killed two snowmobilers.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sacramento Bee newspaper reported that a 21-year-old skier died in an avalanche in the Sierra on Christmas morning.  The newspaper reported that the skier's body was found buried following an avalanche in the Red Dog area at Squaw Valley Ski Resort.  The victim was a resident of Tahoe City.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought over two feet of snow to parts of the Sierra Nevada and a rare white Christmas to much of western Nevada.
Strong north wind produced by a strong low in the Gulf of Alaska resulted in re suspension of snow. The resulting blowing snow produce blizzard conditions through Thompson Pass.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & E JACKSON / LARIMER / N & NE GRAND / NW BOULDER COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two snowmobilers were killed on the side of Gravel Mountain near Grand Lake.  The avalanche occurred when one of the men tried to assist the other, after his snowmobile had become stuck in the snow.  Both men were buried by the slide and died at the scene of the accident.  Another snowmobiler was partially buried in the avalanche, but was not injured.

An avalanche occurred within the boundaries of the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort resulting in the death of a 31-year-old male. The slide carried the victim and his uninjured companion 200 yards. The depth of the avalanche was six to eight feet and completely buried the victim. The area had undergone avalanche hazard reduction efforts that morning and had previously been skied that day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Layers of weak and unstable snow followed by sustained, heavy snowfall, created avalanche prone conditions that gave way to a snowmobile induced avalanche during the afternoon hours of January 4. Three snowmobilers were riding up a snow-covered hill about six miles south of the Marapos Creek trailhead in Rio Blanco county south of Hamilton, when the avalanche occurred and buried one of the snowmobilers head first into the snow. The two other snowmobilers recovered the victim who was unconscious at the time, but regained consciousness shortly thereafter. He was taken to Memorial Hospital in Craig and then to Aurora Hospital.  The victim suffered some pulmonary problems from the snowmobile exhaust that filled his lungs with carbon monoxide while he was trapped underneath the snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowmobilers triggered an avalanche in Rio Blanco County.

An avalanche swept across Teton Pass near milepost 13 around 2200MST closing the road. Debris depth was estimated at 12 to 15 feet. The apparent trigger for the slide was a moose whose carcass was found among the debris. The road remained closed until 0700MST the following day.

An in-bounds avalanche slammed into the Bridger Restaurant at Jackson Hole Mountain Resort at 0926MST after being triggered by a ski patrol bomb. The slide injured five ski patrollers and caused damage to the restaurant deck. One of the patrollers was buried in snow up to his neck. The force of the avalanche blasted through doors and windows, piling snow up to eight feet deep inside the building. At least a dozen feet of snow was pushed against the back wall of the restaurant.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 42 year old man was caught in a backcountry avalanche near Vail. His leg was broken as a result of the avalanche.  Search and rescue crews helped the victim off the mountain and transported him to a medical facility.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A man was injured after being caught in an avalanche.

Extreme avalanche danger in the Teton Range necessitated avalanche mitigation efforts by the Wyoming Department of Transportation. A bomb dropped from a helicopter triggered one slide that pushed snow over 40 feet deep across Teton Pass at the Glory Bowl at 0800MST. Crews worked throughout the day to clear the snow from the road which was reopened at 1900MST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A father and his three sons left the Bear River Service trailhead in the Western Uinta Mountains for a day of snowmobiling on the morning of December 30th. They eventually made their way to Yamaha Hill (which Utah riders call Avalanche Hill), where one of the sons triggered a large avalanche. He got carried by the avalanche and was killed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche in the western Uinta Mountains caught and killed one snowmobiler.

An ice climber was killed when an avalanche one-quarter mile across swept 2,000 feet down a mountainside and spilled over the edge of a steep slope he was climbing. His climbing partner was uninjured. The two climbers experienced two smaller avalanches prior to the fatal slide during their more than 1,000 foot ascent. The slide occurred on The Main Vein, a popular climbing spot on the upper South Fork of the Shoshone River.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST SLOPES OF THE CENTRAL CASCADES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Hyak, 8 houses were damaged by an 300 feet wide landslide and avalanche of snow, dirt and trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall on deep snowpack caused excessive runoff and moderate flooding on the Yakima River from near Easton to the mouth.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A party of two snowboarders and one skier were hiking up a slope near Eiseman Hut in the Gore Range when they were caught and buried in an avalanche.  They all came to rest fairly quickly after being carried about 20 vertical feet.  All three were completely buried; the skier and one snowboarder under 1 to 3 feet of snow, while the other snowboarder was under 6 to 7 feet of snow.  The skier was able to dig himself out of the snow after 1 hour and 20 minutes.  The skier then dug out his partners who had been buried under the snow for up to 2 hours and 15 minutes.  All three activated their AvaLungs after they were buried by the snow, and this safety equipment was instrumental in saving their lives.  The three backcountry travelers suffered only minor injuries, though some of their equipment was damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three snowboarders were caught in an avalanche.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A natural avalanche came down upon a section of Highway 550 near Red Mountain Pass and closed the road for one hour and 20 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A natural avalanche covered a section of Highway 550 near Red Mountain Pass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A party of skiers triggered an avalanche while skiing in Bear Creek, near the Telluride ski area. The avalanche carried one skier 1400 vertical feet over several cliff bands, to the valley floor. His entire body was buried except for one hand. He was rescued about 7 minutes later by other members in his party, and was carried out by the Telluride Helitrax and Telluride Ski Patrol. The victim suffered multible broken bones and was taken to St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Skiers triggered an avalanche while skiing near Telluride.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pair of avalanches occurred in the Arctic Circle area just west of Big Bear. The avalanches left 15 foot high piles of snow on Highway 18, trapping about one dozen cars.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long wave upper trough and a pair of upper-level lows and surface cold fronts brought periods of gusty winds, heavy rain, and mountain snow between February 5th and February 10th. On February 7th, thunderstorms developed in the unstable air behind the first cold front. These storms produced small hail in several locations and a waterspout. The heaviest rain and snow fell on February 9th, when the second strong cold front and upper-level jet moved over the region. Heavy snow in the mountains snapped trees and power lines, causing loss of power to approximately 10,000 residents. Many mountain highways were closed, including Highway 18 when a pair of avalanches buried part of the road. Rainfall totals for the five days were upwards of 2 inches in the coast and valley locations, up to about 6 inches in the foothills.

A group of four snowmobilers triggered a mile long, 100 yard wide avalanche in the Deadhorse Creek drainage near Alpine in Lincoln County. The group rode into a draw after dropping off a ridge line and the slab broke loose taking the lives of three men as they tried to outrun the slide. The lone survivor was able to get one hand above the snow and dig himself out. He then walked out and used a cell phone to call for help. The three victims were found more than two hours later under about three feet of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A ski patrolman was partially buried in an avalanche at Squaw Valley Ski Resort while he was working avalanche controls.  He was dug out of the avalanche by another member of the ski patrol.  He was transferred to Renown Regional Medical Center in Reno but later died from his injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm moved through the northern and central Sierra Nevada and western Nevada.

A 50 year old Enterprise, Oregon man died in an avalanche while backcountry skiing in the Eagle Cap Wilderness.   Two other people were rescued. The quarter mile long slap avalanche occurred about 1 pm.  Heavy snow had fallen in the area earlier in the week.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 12 inches across northern portions of the area with 4 or less inches in southern areas, and some locations only receiving rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong, moist, and unseasonably cold winter storm struck the central intermountain region. Heavy snowfall occurred in most areas across eastern Utah and western Colorado. Additionally, strong winds in the southern portions of eastern Utah and western Colorado produced blizzard conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report came from www.avalanche.org. ||A party of 2 skiers was descending the west face of Garfield peak in Crater Lake National Park at 7800 ft.. The first skier was in the upper bowl when the slope avalanched with the crown 10-14 inches deep and approximately 900 ft. wide. He was carried down slope 400 vertical feet when he slammed into a stand of trees on the edge of the avalanche pathway above a small cliff. The snow continued down another 600 vertical feet to the road. He was partially buried and tangled on a tree. The other skier extricated him and assisted him to the road where he was then transported to the hospital. His main injury was a separated pelvis and was discharged 4 days later.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow created unstable slope conditions across southern Oregon and northern California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Idaho Mountain Express reported that a young man died in an avalanche while snowmobiling at Rock Lake in the French Creek drainage outside of Cascade, Idaho.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm with a significant Pacific moisture tap moved into the Intermountain West spreading heavy, wet snow across parts of Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho on the 15th and 16th of December.
An avalanche, 200 feet wide,  buried and killed a snowmobiler from La Pine, Oregon on Paulina Peak which is south of Bend.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two snowboarders rode down the northwest face of a mountain about four miles northeast of Silverton. The first rider ski cut the top of the open face above the trees, and then rode down 100 vertical feet. The second snowboarder began riding down the slope and triggered an avalanched that started with an upper face fracture of 3 feet deep and 50 feet wide. The first snowboarder waiting below could not escape the slide path and pinned himself on the uphill side of a tree. The slide moved through his location and buried him to mid thigh. The two snowmobilers then proceeded down the avalanche path, which was between 400 and 500 vertical feet. There were no injuries.  The exact time of the avalanche is unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowboarder was caught in an avalanche near Silverton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 33-year old Billings man was killed in an avalanche on Scotch Bonnet Mountain near Cooke City. He had gotten stuck and was trying to free his snowmobile when the slide occurred.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 33-year old Billings man was killed in an avalanche on Scotch Bonnet Mountain near Cooke City. He had gotten stuck and was trying to free his snowmobile when the slide occurred.

A member of the Jackson Hole Ski Area ski patrol was critically injured in a human triggered avalanche in the resort's Cheyenne Bowl. The victim succumbed to his injuries on Saturday, January 9, after spending several days in an area hospital. The patroller was conducting routine avalanche hazard reduction duties when he was caught in the slide. He had previously thrown one hand charge onto the slope before throwing two additional charges which fractured the slope above him. The man traveled an estimated 1,000 feet and over a 25-foot cliff while trapped in the avalanche. He was found unconscious under about six feet of snow. Another patroller was caught in the slide but clung to a tree to save himself.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowboarder was assumed to have exited Vail Ski Area in Blue Sky Basin, where he proceeded toward the Miller Cliffs on Battle Mountain. While attempting to snowboard outside of ski area boundaries, he triggered 2 small avalanches that came together and carried him roughly 100 feet downhill. He was carried into a stand of trees where he was partially buried head-first and suffocated under 3 feet of snow. The snowboarder was alone and was not recovered until nearly a week later on January 14. Therefore, the time of this accident is estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early January snowfall overloaded an underlying weak snow surface, causing a deadly avalanche to occur just outside of Vail Mountains Ski Area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier triggered a slab avalanche in Picayne Gulch about 9 miles northeast of Silverton.  The skier was 10-15 feet below the fracture line when the avalanche started.  The skier was carried about 150 yards and was buried to his neck.  Two other skiers descended the slope and extricated the victim within about 10 minutes.  The avalanche also ran across San Juan County Road 2 at the base of the slope.  No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A skier was caught in an avalanche in Picayne Gulch northeast of Silverton.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier triggered an avalanche at the 10,500 foor level in the Mushroom Bowl area near Vail Ski Area. The avalanche path was about 80 feet wide and ran about 650 vertical feet. The skier was caught in the avalanche and partially buried, sustaining minor injuries.  Two other skiers rescued the victim and the Vail Ski Patrol later responded to the incident.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three people were caught in an out-of-bounds avalanche near Vail Ski Area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two snowmobilers were riding in an area about a half mile west of Rabbit Ears Pass.  One of the snowmobilers went up an untracked slope to make the first highmark.  The second snowmobiler started up shortly thereafter and got stuck before the first snowmobiler was off the slope. The first snowmobiler then turned and was sidehilling over to the second snowmobiler's location when the avalanche released. The avalanche caught and partially buried the second snowmobiler.  No injuries or damage were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler was caught in an avalanche near Rabbit Ears Pass.

CZ_NAME_STR: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An avalanche near the bottom of Fire Trail on Seattle Ridge on Bald Mountain killed a back country skier.  The avalanche occurred at approximately 2:30 pm on January 22nd.   The man was pronounced dead at 3:31 pm at the Wood River Medical Center due to suffocation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalanche near the bottom of Fire Trail on Seattle Ridge on Bald Mountain killed a back country skier.  The avalanche occurred at approximately 2:30 pm on January 22nd.   The man was pronounced dead at 3:31 pm at the Wood River Medical Center due to suffocation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the northwest side of Animas Mountain within the Durango city limits, an avalanche roared into a house. The homeowners were about to move into the 15 year old home within the following 2 weeks. Snow blasted through an exterior wall and blew loose drywall onto an interior wall. One bedroom was completely filled with snow, and the home suffered severe structural damage. The avalanche ran about 600 vertical feet with a 150 foot wide path. The damaged home was discovered Sunday, January 24, but the actual time of the avalanche is unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms brought anywhere from 1 to over 3 feet of snow to the Durango area, which caused an avalanche to release in the San Juan mountains that blasted into a vacant home.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Following several days of fresh snowfall, a skier triggered an avalanche just out-of-bounds of the Snowbasin resort, in the area known as Hell's Canyon. He was caught, carried, and partially buried by the avalanche. By the time other skiers and rescuers got to him, he had already passed away.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A skier was caught, carried, and killed by an avalanche in Hell's Canyon, in the |Snowbasin backcountry.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler with a sled got stuck in flats below a mountain slope near Irwin Lodge. A second snowmobiler drove just above the stuck snowmobiler and triggered three separate avalanches. One of the avalanches came down onto the stuck snowmobiler. His sled rolled on top of him and he was partially buried with his head and hand just above the snow.  The path of that avalanche was 400 vertical feet and was 80 feet wide.  No significant injuries or damage were reported.  The time of the avalanche is an estimate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler was caught in an avalanche west of Crested Butte.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four experienced backcountry skiers headed out-of-bounds and toward Old Man's Bowl just outside of the East Vail area. One of the skiers attempted to ski down the bowl and made a ski cut below the ridgeline heading towards the tree band which separates two portions of East Marvin's. He triggered a small soft slab avalanche  which ran about 200 vertical feet onto a bench. The skier then skied onto and below the bench and triggered a second soft slab avalanche that was about 100 feet wide and ran 400 vertical feet. The skier attempted to ski out to the side and out of the way of the debris flow. While looking over his shoulder he lost his balance, fell, and was caught in the debris and washed down the slope. The skier was buried with his head just below the snow surface.  The other skiers in the group were able to dig him out of the snow. The buried skier sustained a broken arm and several cuts and bruises to his head and limbs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Vail Ski Area reported over 2 feet of snow in a seven day period followed by strong west to northwest winds that transported snow and built fresh, unstable slabs. These unstable snow pack conditions resulted in an avalanche release just outside of Vail Ski Area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier triggered an avalanche in an area known as Meadows, a backcountry area in Big Cottonwood Canyon, out-of-bounds of nearby Solitude Ski Resort. The avalanche buried the victim; he was found and dug out less than an hour after the avalanche occurred, but had already passed away.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another avalanche fatality occurred on January 27th, this one in the Meadows area of Big Cottonwood Canyon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man was snowmobiling with some friends on Grandview Peak, east of the city of Bountiful, when he and another man triggered an avalanche. The other man was able to outrun the avalanche on his snowmobile, but the victim was not, and he was buried under about 6 feet of snow. He was buried for approximately 15-18 minutes, before being completely dug out, and was flown to University Hospital in Salt Lake in extremely critical condition. He passed away two days later.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler was caught and killed in an avalanche on Grandview Peak, in the Session Mountains, east of Bountiful, Utah.

Considerable avalanche danger across western Wyoming created dangerous conditions for snowmobiling. The Bridger-Teton National Forest Avalanche Center reported at least 13 slides on February 6. One avalanche near Murphy Lake Road buried a snowmobiler up to his goggles. The man deployed an avalanche airbag to avoid being buried.

A snowmobiler who became stuck in the snow and triggered an avalanche was killed in the Squaw Creek area in western Wyoming. The man had stepped off his machine in an attempt to free his snowmobile from the snow. At the same time, the 150-foot-wide slab broke loose along a south-facing slope at an elevation of approximately 9000 feet. The man was carried by the avalanche and was buried for 15 to 20 minutes, despite being located quickly because of an avalanche beacon he was wearing.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven back-country skiers ventured out on a hut trip near the Ridgeway Hut in the northern San Juan Mountains when two of the skiers were caught in an avalanche. Nearby observations indicated anywhere from 10 to 16 inches of fresh snow had fallen in the 6 days leading up to the event. The skiers were attempting their second run of the day when they decided to split into two groups. One of the skiers in the second group triggered the slide which then carried two of the skiers about 400 feet downhill. One skier was completely buried under 1 to 2 feet of snow, while the other skier was thrown into a large tree. Other party members carrying rescue equipment immediately began searching for the caught skiers. Both skiers were dug out of the snow and brought to the hospital in Montrose by rescue helicopter. The buried skier did not survive, while the other skier suffered multiple traumatic injuries, including a dislocated hip.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several inches of fresh snow fell on top of an unstable snow-pack leading to a skier triggered avalanche which carried two skiers and resulted in one fatality.

An avalanche in Jules Bowl northwest of Dubois near Pinnacle Buttes buried a man in snow up to his head. It took his companions about 30 minutes to uncover him and remove a snowmobile from resting on his leg. He was responsive during the recovery.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A group of four back-country skiers were skinning up Mt. Yeckel to attempt their second run for the day, when the lead skier triggered an avalanche. The avalanche carried the first skier 100 feet downhill, where he then hit a tree. The second of the four skiers was also carried downhill but remained on top of the snow surface. The remaining two skiers were able to stay out of the avalanche path. The uninjured skiers contacted Mountain Rescue Aspen, who attended to the injured skier around 3:00 am the next morning. He was flown out by helicopter about 3 hours later and was diagnosed with a broken lower leg.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A group of back-country skiers triggered an avalanche on Mt. Yeckel above the town of Lenado.

An avalanche on South Teton peak pushed a 30-year-old man off a 1500-foot cliff to his death. The man and two ski companions had earlier climbed the peak and had skied down several hundred feet below the summit when the slide triggered around 1100MST. The other two skiers were unhurt.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the week leading up to the date of the accident, Aspen Mountain, which is the closest observing site, reported up to 35 inches of new snowfall. Weak layers underneath the fresh snow created a very unstable snowpack, which lead to the deadly avalanche. A group of 6 people were staying at the Lindley Hut near Ashcroft, and on the day of the accident, 3 people in the group ventured out to ski some of the lower slopes near the hut. The skiers were skinning up a slope about a quarter mile east of the hut, when the first skier triggered a slide that carried him 150 feet downhill and buried him underneath 3 feet of snow in a dense stand of trees. The two other skiers did not witness the initial trigger of the slide, but began to search for the victim after seeing what happened. They contacted Mountain Rescue Aspen who were flown into the site the next morning and eventually found the victim near the toe of the avalanche debris.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall from a strong winter storm was deposited onto a weak, preexisting snow-pack, which lead to a deadly skier triggered avalanche just above the Lindley Hut near Ashcroft.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of February 26th, a group of four back-country skiers exited the Aspen Mountain Ski Area boundaries and entered into Ophir Gulch. Two of the skiers in the group were on the steeper part of the terrain when an avalanche was triggered by one of them. The other skier was below digging a pit when the avalanche began and was carried a short distance by the slide before he was able to grab hold of a tree and avoid being swept further downhill. The other skier, who initially triggered the slide, was carried 500 vertical feet and was buried on the uphill side of a tree. The buried skier was quickly found and attended to by his partners, but the rescue required the assistance of nine Aspen Mountain Ski Patrol members. The victim who sustained serious chest and neck injuries was brought to an ambulance by 8:40 pm that evening.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm brought heavy snow to the mountains near Aspen throughout the week leading up to the accident. This added a significant load to the underlying weak snow surface and resulted in an avalanche just outside of Aspen Mountain Ski Area.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES CENTRAL CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier was injured when an avalanche he created slammed him into a tree.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A skier was injured when an avalanche he created slammed him into a tree.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One male snowmobiler was ascending a slope near Cliff Lake Overlook in the Flat Tops Wilderness Area when he triggered an avalanche. The rider fell off of his machine near the top of the slope, which triggered the slide. He and his machine were carried about 100 feet downhill, but he was able to ride the avalanche in a sitting position and was only partially buried.  The victim did not sustain any serious injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler triggered an avalanche in the Flat Tops area of the White River National Forest.
A snowmobiler perished in a avalanche in northern Saguache County near Marshall Pass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 1:00 pm on March 17th, two cross country skiers attempted to ski the Thunderbird area on the west side of the Grand Mesa. The skiers were passing through a clearing when a wall of snow above them collapsed. They were both carried an estimated 300 to 800 feet down slope. One of the skiers was dragged into several trees and seriously injured. The second skier was able to contact the Sheriff's Department, who dispatched a search and rescue team that eventually airlifted them to St. Mary's Hospital where the injured skier was put into the intensive care unit. The injured skier suffered two broken legs from the accident.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two cross country skiers were caught in an avalanche on the Grand Mesa and one of them sustained serious injuries.

CZ_NAME_STR: UPPER RIO GRANDE VALLEY / EASTERN SAN JUAN MOUNTAINS BELOW 10000 FT (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two men were buried and perished when up to 2 1/2 feet of snow slid off a cabin roof 17 miles west of Creede.  This was the first instance of a fatal roof avalanche since 1996 in Vail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 17 inches were reported on the northern side of the San Juan mountains just prior to the date of this event, which contributed to unstable snow conditions. A group of 8 back-country skiers headed into the mountains northwest of Silverton for an advanced back-country skiing course. After ascending the slope, the first skier in the group skied down and stopped in a safe patch of trees to wait for the others. The next 5 skiers descended one at a time about 1,000 feet downhill and stopped to wait for the others. The seventh skier descended and fell into a small concavity which released the slide that propagated out in both directions. Only the first and seventh skier were caught and carried in the avalanche, but were both able to recover with no injuries. None of the other skiers were affected.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A group of 8 back-country skiers were participating in an advanced back-country skiing course when one of the skiers triggered an avalanche.

Two cross-country skiers were caught in an avalanche in Wolf Creek Canyon on the west side of Casper Mountain at 0950MST. One skier was able to extricate himself before digging out his companion who was submerged in snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms in March brought several feet of snow to the San Juan Mountains, including the storm leading up to this event which deposited 21 inches of new snowfall at the nearest observation site. The date of this event was the warmest day of the season to date with strong southerly winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to around 60 mph. All of these factors combined to produce what was believed to be a natural avalanche near Baldy Peak. A very experienced back-country traveler and certified alpine mountain guide with professional avalanche training headed out to attempt a remote ice climb on the northeast side of Baldy Peak when she was caught in the avalanche. Because she was traveling alone, many of the details of this event are unknown or estimated. The following day a search and rescue team found the avalanche site along with some of the climber's equipment and her dog, but were unsuccessful in finding the climber. They returned the following day with a larger team and eventually found the body of the missing climber buried under 5 to 6 feet of snow and debris.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow in the San Juan Mountains combined with weak underlying snow surfaces and the warmest temperatures of the season so far to produce a fatal avalanche near Baldy Peak, southeast of the town of Ridgeway.
Two Washington state men died in an avalanche while snowmobiling about 17 miles north of McCall, Idaho. The size of the avalanche was estimated to be between 5 and 6 acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One snowmobiler was killed in an avalanche that he triggered on Sunday, April 4th. He was traveling north along a ridge, when a cornice he was on, cracked and broke off. This caused an avalanche to release below the cornice. He was carried over a cliff band. He was buried approximately 1,000 feet below the ridge under 2 to 3 feet of debris. He was located by his partner with a beacon, and was taken away from the scene via helicopter. However, the helicopter medical crew could not find a pulse, and the man was pronounced dead an hour later.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm took a three day period to move through northern Utah, bringing heavy wet snow to the area. Though the snowfall remained primarily in northern Utah, southern Utah received strong gusty winds as this storm moved through the region. The combination of snowfall and strong winds in northern Utah also produced hazardous avalanche conditions, with one fatal avalanche during this period of time.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES CENTRAL CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A skier was injured when an avalanche slammed him into a tree in the Commonwealth Basin are just north of Snoqualmie Pass.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people were injured in two separate avalanches near Snoqualmie Pass.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES CENTRAL CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A hiker spent about 4 hours partially buried in an avalanche.  He was hypothermic when found.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people were injured in two separate avalanches near Snoqualmie Pass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong wind event the previous day resulted in the release of at least 3 natural avalanches that ran across Highway 550 in the Uncompahgre Gorge area, closing the highway for a period of time. The avalanche deposits on the highway ranged from 1 to 5 feet deep and from 20 to 80 foot long sections of the highway.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong wind event the previous day lead to a few natural avalanches in the Uncompahgre Gorge through the overnight hours of April 13th.

CZ_NAME_STR: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two skiers climbed up the east face of Castle Peak during the late morning hours of the 24th. After performing several snow stability tests, the skiers saw no potential avalanche risk. Skier one was the first to descend the mountain when a slab released above him and carried him downhill. He was just coming to a stopping point when another slab released and hit him in the back, which propelled him even further downhill. The skier was carried about 750 feet, but managed to stay upright and on top of the snow surface. The skier was buried up to his boots but managed to ski out with only a minor leg injury.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two skiers headed up Castle Peak in the Elk Mountains when they encountered an avalanche that carried one skier downhill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two climbers were descending Hangerman Peak when a block of cornice broke off of a ridge above them and struck both climbers. The two of them were carried an estimated 1,000 vertical feet. A helicopter was needed to rescue one of the climbers who was injured from the slide. The time of the event is estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two climbers were caught while descending Hangerman Peak.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowboarder was injured when he triggered an avalanche at the Nitro Chute on Berthoud Pass.  He suffered a back injury when he was transported over a cliff band.  The severity of his injuries was unknown.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to the North Central Mountains of Colorado.  Storm totals included:  19.5 inches at Columbine SNOTEL, 16.5 inches at Never Summer, 15 inches at Joe Wright, 13.5 inches at Jones Pass and Phantom Valley SNOTEL, 12 inches at the Loveland, Tower and Zirkel SNOTEL sites; 10.5 inches at Grizzly Peak and Stillwater Creek; and 10 inches near Grand Lake.  Lesser amounts of 4 to 9 inches were observed elsewhere.  In addition, a snowboarder was injured in an avalanche over Berthoud Pass.

CZ_NAME_STR: EASTERN SAN JUAN MOUNTAINS ABOVE 10000 FT (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An avalanche at Wolf Creek Ski Area killed the Wolf Creek Ski Area Director.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blizzard, avalanche and winter storm conditions impacted the eastern San Juan Mountains, La Garita Mountains, and eastern Sawatch Range. Winds gusted to around 70 mph at times in the eastern San Juan Mountains.  In addition to the snow and the wind...an avalanche killed the Wolf Creek Ski Area Director.  Snow totals were in excess of 8 inches across the eastern Sawatch Range and La Garita Mountains and Upper Rio Grande Valley.  Up to 18 inches of snow fell across the eastern half of Wolf Creek Pass in Mineral County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two experienced snowmobilers from Evanston, Wyoming were riding in the Humpy Creek drainage in the western Uinta Mountains. Since they did not plan to ride on steep terrain, they left their avalanche beacons and shovels in their vehicles. One rider, a 54 year old man, apparently decided to at least partially ascend a popular snowmobile slope called Cherry Hill, where he triggered an avalanche and was buried. By the time his friend was able to get help, he had been buried under two feet of snow for more than half an hour, and he died at the scene.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An experienced snowmobiler got caught in an avalanche in Utah's Uinta Mountains. He was buried by the snow and died at the scene.

CZ_NAME_STR: WEST SLOPES CENTRAL CASCADES AND PASSES (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A climber was killed by an avalanche in a steep confined gully in the central Cascades.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A climber was killed by an avalanche in a steep confined gully in the central Cascades.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two skiers were caught in an avalanche along Dry Gulch, which is east of the Eisenhower Tunnel.  One skier was killed when he was buried under 2 to 3 feet of snow; the other suffered minor injuries.  It took approximately 15 minutes for the injured skier to locate his friend, and another 15 minutes to excavate him and initiate CPR.

A snowboarder triggered an avalanche south of the No Shadows couloir. The avalanche buried the snowboarder in 15 feet of debris and left only his fingers exposed above the slab. He was rescued and reported only minor injuries.

CZ_NAME_STR: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A snowmobiler was injured when he triggered an avalanche near Jones Pass, in near whiteout conditions.  Visibilities at the time ranged from 10 feet to 100 feet.  He was caught and buried in the slide that was approximately 100 feet long.  While in the avalanche, he discharged his airbag which helped him to float to the surface.  The snowmobiler was partially buried in approximately 6 to 18 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulations of 12 to 20 inches were measured across the area.  Wind gusts of 20 to 40 mph produced areas of blowing and drifting snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and very moist westerly flow aloft with embedded disturbances resulted in heavy snowfall accumulations, especially in the mountains.
An avalanche in Granite Canyon left an out-of-bounds skier injured after carrying him 1,000 feet. He was not buried in the slide. The skier triggered the slab in the Double Dog Leg chute.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three avalanches occurred on Mount Charleston in the Echo and Cathedral subdivisions.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storms fueled by a tropical moisture tap pounded the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin for several days.  Extremely heavy snow and widespread flooding resulted.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter in Dixie reported 14 inches of snow and a spotter in Powell reported 13 inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Pacific storm system with abundant moisture interacted with a very cold arctic air mass to produce heavy snow with areas of blowing snow and very cold wind chill temperatures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Missoula sheriff's office reported that 3 skiers were caught in an avalanche when they were sking outside of the ski area boundaries. One skier was injured but alert.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An avalance swept away 3 skiers when they were sking outside of the ski area boundaries.
